subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Hi Kent, Are you suggesting that groupping test classes per fixture will be the only supported option in JUnit4? I d say that this could be ok for small
messageBody:
Hi Kent,

Are you suggesting that groupping test classes per fixture will be
the only supported option in JUnit4?

I'd say that this could be ok for small projects but for projects
with thousands tests it will not make any easier to see all the tests
for any changed class. Also note that it is also bad option to rerun
all tests because there are too many of them to be runned on each change.

Of course there are some tools, but it is not always possible to
use them.

regards,
Eugene


Kent Beck wrote:
> Eugene,
>
> I don't organize my tests with one test class per model class.
> Instead, I have one test class per fixture. For example, if I wanted
> to test with both empty lists and lists with elements, I would have
> two classes:
>
> class EmptyListTest {
> List<String> list;
> @Before public void initialize() {
> list= new ArrayList<String>();
> }
> ...
> }
>
> class PopulatedListTest {
> List<String> list;
> @Before public void initialize() {
> list= new ArrayList<String>();
> list.add("one");
> list.add("two");
> }
> ...
> }
>
> Following this style, different test methods in a single
> parameterized test class will all share the same parameters.
>
> The JUnit tests are not currently organized very well with respect
> to this principle. I find that when I am in a hurry to write the next
> test I tend to put it in the same test class as the last test. I need
> to 1) re-organize the JUnit tests and 2) slow down a little.
>
> I always err on the side of running too many tests, so I don't find
>
> it hugely annoying to run all the tests related to a change even when
> I have multiple test classes per model class.
>
> Sincerely yours,
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute
